What is the xeno effect?

 
 
 A watched quantum pot will not boil. If you observer a plasma of barium particles, and then put energy into them, it takes x amount of time for all the ions to go into the next energy state. if you observe at the plasma cloud at x/2, half the ions have moved into the next state. However, if you decrease the time slice between masurements to a small enough interval, the ions to not flip up into the next energy state. This is an experment that shows that observing something changes the outcome. (QM is freaky stuff, and very counter intititive to me).
 
 Since the ions don't flip into the next energy state while being observed, yet will flip up otherwise, that tells me there is no 'observer' to watch them to flip up into the next energy state.

Belief in one's perceptions of the world is very different from belief in the supernatural.  I believe that the difference in belief in one's perceptions of the world and belief in the supernatural is a matter of degree, not something more fundamental. You can't prove that God exists, you also can't prove that you're reading this. There is no way for you to prove, even to yourself, that your perception of the comupter screen in front of you is based on reality, and not a hallucination or an implanted memory or any of a dozen other explanations. You just take it on faith. Now, that having been said, I do believe that degree of faith needed to believe one's senses is tiny compared to the amount needed to believe in God. The first is such a tiny leap that most would call it common sense. The later is of course a huge leap.
 
 

 Reason is the agreed upon belief system that lets us function in the world. Are you conceding that a belief in God has no logical reason?

 I cannot understand how you support the statement, "there is no logical reason to believe that you need a logical reason to believe everything."
 

 I don't see how you can't. You believe a bunch of things, right? Can you logically justify all those beliefs? For example, I believe my wife loves me. I can't prove it, but I know it's true. I believe that there's life somewhere else in the universe. I have no logical justification for it, by I still think it's true. I believe the universe is pretty much as I perceive it, I believe the human condition will improve, I believe lots of things without any logical support.
 
 Just to clarify, I am most emphatically not saying that you should believe something that has logically shown to be false. I'm a firm believer in logic; if logic shows something to be true or false than I'll go with what logic says. But if you can't logically say yay or nay on a subject I don't see that one must refuse to hold an opinion. Certainly nothing in logic says that you can't; it just says that you can't use logic to justify your belief.

 This is, of course, an entire debate unto itself. I fully concede that logic dictates that we accept the possibility of life elsewhere. But that it's probable? We simply don't have the data to make that leap. We've got some good theories about how life started here, but we don't know exactly what happened. And even if we did, we don't know how common those conditions are "out there". If the conditions for life to arise are so bizarre that they only occur once every 20 billion years, and for all we know they might be, than we may well be the only life in the universe. Logically, we just can't say. We don't have enough info to apply logic to the problem.

What was it about Sagan that made him a giant?

 For me it's the way he made science accessible to non-scientists. He was a teacher. IMO nothing is more heroic than that.
 
 "I would love to believe that when I die I will live again, that some thinking, feeling, remembering part of me will continue. But much as I want to believe that, and despite the ancient and worldwide cultural traditions that assert an afterlife, I know of nothing to suggest that it is more than wishful thinking."
 
 "The world is so exquisite with so much love and moral depth, that there is no reason to deceive ourselves with pretty stories for which there's little good evidence.  Just to clarify. I believe that a beleif in God is not supported by logic. Illogical can be taken to mean "contrary to logic" or "countered by logic", which is not what I'm saying. The definition I gave before, an omnipotent omniscient being that works in mysterious ways, can't be shown to not exist via logic. 

 
 I don't I see a difference between "not supported by logic" and illogical. I am not trying to show that God does not exist, I am saying there is no logical reason to say that he does. As such, that is contrary to everything else I believe in the world. I use my senses and reason to believe everything. 
 
 I believe it is going to rain today. Why? It looks cloudy and gray and the weather report said so. I believe the earth revolves aroung the sun. Why, I have read it in science texts. And it also seems to make sense based on my perception of the world and my other knowledge of science. 
 
 How do I know that all these science books are true? Well, they all corroborate each other. No one is disagreeing. I cannot conceive of any logical reason why all these scientists would be putting in all this effort to deceive me. Also, the stuff makes sense to me, given all the other information I understand about the world.
 
 If given new information, would I change my beliefs? Of course, why not?
 
 Belief in God is not like that. It is based on old books written by sources who did not document empirical findings. Many cultures create deities to explain what is at that time unexplainable. Since the Renaissance, humans have changed the way we think about everything and continue to change as new information comes to light. The only area of thought that stagnates is religion and spirituality. 
 
 I am not trying to deny the absolute existence of sometimes profound spiritual experiences most definitely do occur. Humans seem to have a capacity for that experience. I am just saying we should not explain them with reason that have no basis in fact. 
 
 It is in only in religion that we are able to get away with behaving illogically. Tell a devout Christian that his wife is cheating on him, or that frozen yogurt can make a man invisible, and he is likely to require as much evidence as anyone else, and to be persuaded only to the extent that you give it. Tell him that the book he keeps by his bed was written by an invisible deity who will punish him with fire for eternity if he fails to accept its every incredible claim about the universe, and he seems to require no evidence whatsoever.
 
 Thats all I'm saying.

OK, I know I'm jumping in here but here's my two pence worth:
 
 While I realise that everything I sense could just be fed to me through some kind of artificial reality environment, I have nothing else to go on: I remember first reading of this idea in various SF novels while a mere stripling, and it blew my mind, but only briefly. I quickly realised that even if this were the case, my response would essentially be: "So what?"
 
 All I am, unless some future genius geneticist can prove otherwise, is the sum of my experiences; therefore any spurious ideas of my brain existing in a jar are irrelevant; if I were to awake as that brain and were given a new body in whatever fantastical realm I would inhabit, my personality, my responses to stimuli, my reasoning, would still be based on my fictional experiences within the artificial world created by my cerebral captors. 
 Likewise if I were to awake, finding that my life so far was a dream within a coma, and I was older or younger than I am now, my dreamed experiences would still form the sum of my personality, regardless of the 'truth' of the acual existing reality. I would still be me.
 
 And as for aliens, I am unfortunately with Kronus on this one; we simply do not know how likely it is for intelligent life (I assume that this is the crux of the matter) to emerge. There are 100 billion stars in the galaxy, even if 0.001% have an earth-like planet that is still 100 million! Then there are at least 10 billion galaxies within the 'observable' universe which is pretty certain to be a small fraction of the totality.
 However, it took us 4.5 billion years to emerge from a lifeless lump of boiling rock, 1/3 the age of the universe! Two questions thereof:
 
 1) How do we know we are not the first?
 
 2) What are the chances of a comparable civilisation arising near enough to us that we will ever encounter them?
 
 Answers:
 
 1) We don't.
 
 2) Based on the only datum available (the length of time it has taken us to get to where we are now), not very high, unless earth-like planets are very common, which we can only guess at.

I really understand where you are coming from about our senses. It gets absurd, however, if we cannot, as a given, agree that reality is pretty much what we perceive with our senses. Otherwise, I don't see how we can discuss anything. Even if we are in pods and this is all the matrix, at least we all are on the same playing field.

 OK. I was just repeating the example of life out there that you gave. I meant that the universe is way stinking big and it's possible that the events of earth may also have occurred somewhere else. This is a tenuous belief I have, actually a guess, and I could be persuaded otherwise. 
 

 That's pretty much what I was trying to illustrate. It's a belief you have, a guess if you will, that isn't based on logic. 
 
 

 I don't I see a difference between "not supported by logic" and illogical.

 A key point in my argument, allow me to illustrate:
 
 I show you a shoebox, but don't let you examine it closely. I ask you to believe that there's a brick in it. A brick would certainly fit, but you have no evidence that there is actually a brick in there. If you chose to believe, your belief would be "not supported by logic". It could be true, it might not be, you have no way of saying. If instead I asked you to believe that there was a full grown African elephant in the shoebox, that belief would be illogical. You would have to either ignore logic or throw out some basic axiom about the universe to believe that an elephant would fit in a shoebox. My contention is that belief in God isn't illogical, by that defintion, but merely not suported by logic. I'm also contending that not all beliefs must be supported by logic, they should just not be illogical.
 
 
 That having been said, I totally agree with your assesment of how some people treat religion. To take the Bible literally, for example, is totally illogical. However, I have no problem with someone deciding they want to belive in a God of some nature, as long as that belief doesn't drive them to illogical behavior. If it simply makes them happy than I won't say that it's wrong for them to belive just becuase their belief isn't supported by logic.

 It looks like we are simple going to disagree on this: illogical = not supported by logic.
 With the brick, I would believe it is possible for a brick to be in the shoebox - a logical belief. But without further evidence, it would be illogical to believe in more than that. 
 
 Dropping the word logic, how about evidence? I feel beliefs should be based on evidence, empirical or logical.

 Belief in god, yes. Belief in the bible, no. Talking bushes, talking animals, raising the dead, the great flood, the creation myths, are all illogical. Not entirely relevant to the thread, but a point I felt needed addressing anyway.

It looks like we are simple going to disagree on this: illogical = not supported by logic.

 Seems to me that any statement can have three logical values. True, false, or indeterminate. There are some statements that we simply don't have the ability to decide if they are true or false, at least at present. Logically one should believe true statements. Believing false statements is illogical. But if a statement is logically indeterminate, than logic is done with it, it's done all that it can do. At that point you must use some other tool to come to a decision if you think the statement is true or not. Whichever decision you come to won't contratict logic.
 
 Hm. That's crystalized my thinking. When trying to decide if something is true, logic is your first and best tool for deciding. But it's not the only tool. If logic doesn't give you an answer than use another tool. That tool may not be appropriate for convincing other people, and you should recognize that. Also, more evidence may surface, and then logic could become the right tool, but that doesn't mean it's wrong to use the other tool in the meantime.
 
 Sorry to harp on this, but it is central to my line of thinking. If we agree to disagree than we'll be done, and I'm enjoying this discussion. :)
 
 

 With the brick, I would believe it is possible for a brick to be in the shoebox - a logical belief. But without further evidence, it would be illogical to believe in more than that. 
 

 Can you show that? I'm willing to be convinced, but I just don't see it yet. Why is it illogical to believe something without evidence? Let's stick with this example, it's seems to be a good one to me. 
 
 
 

 Dropping the word logic, how about evidence? I feel beliefs should be based on evidence, empirical or logical.

 I think that beliefs shouldn't contradict evidence. If you're going to base actions, or anything meaningful, on your beliefs, then it's a good idea to have your beliefs based on evidence. But if believing something has no real consequences than I don't see that the criteria need to be so strict.
 
 Question: What are you thinking when you say "belief"? I suspect that you might be using a stronger form of the word than I am. To my mind believing that something is true isn't the same as asserting that it's true. If something is logically true than it's definately, certainly true. If I simply believe that something is true than I fully acknowledge that I could be wrong. I'm saying that there's nothing wrong with believing something without evidence; but if evidence comes along that contradicts your belief than you should adjust your belief accordingly. One could say that beliefs based on evidence are "strong" beliefs, while ones without the backing of evidence are "weak" beliefs. Beliefs that contradict evidence are just silly.

No one is saying that faith constitutes a reasonable argument. Faith is in fact exactly the opposite. It's belief despite the lack of a reason to believe. I will say, however, that there is no logical reason to believe that you need a logical reason to believe everything. Is that not so? After all, you can not logically prove the existence of anything except your own self, and that only to yourself. None the less, I'm guessing that you believe that the world is pretty much as you perceive it, despite the lack of any logical reason to do so. You take it on faith. An utterly different level of faith than the kind needed to believe in God, granted, but faith none the less.

I don't I see a difference between "not supported by logic" and illogical. I am not trying to show that God does not exist, I am saying there is no logical reason to say that he does. As such, that is contrary to everything else I believe in the world. I use my senses and reason to believe everything.

 actually there is a difference between what is illogical and what is not supported by logic. kronus gave some good examples, like the probability of life on other planets. there is no real logical basis for believing that lif exists on other planets, but at the same time the belief isnt illogical. thats why not eerything we believe necessarily has to have a logical basis just for us to believe it. there are lots of things we are required to believe to function the way we want to, and logic cannot even be applied in the decision making process. in these cases faith is the only thing to go on. call it gut, instinct, or whatever, its just irreconcilable by logic, yet necessary that we have a belief about it. yet those faith-based beliefs are not necessarily illogical

Since you all here have awfully lot to say about God and what he/she or it has to say or doesn't, answer me this question:
 
 what is God?

 
 This is very simple, so simple it sheds light on something very hard the trinity
 
 GOD IS.... LOVE
 
 
 To learn about God is to learn about love, the most important thing to any and every human being, without love we are nothing, without love we are dead, without love we feel lost, without love we are empty.
 
 With love we can rise to a new life, with love we are found, with love we are fullfilled, with love we are something
 
 God is love
 
 The father of love who brings into existance all things
 The son of love, who reveals to us the true nature of God, love
 The spirit of love, who comes from both the father and the son and inspires in us love and moves us to act in love.
 
 I think its often hard for people to understand just what christians are saying when they are talking about God and Jesus and the holy spirit, I think it may help if you try to keep in mind that God is love and there are three persons of the one divine love, who together are one God...love
